title: entitled buffon chippy ex student no10
story: Surely we deserve better than a bumptious, entitled ­buffoon and a chippy ex- student inhabiting No . Are these two really the brightest and the best  Obviously not. But with politics becoming ever more isive and toxic, they are all we have left.Let’s be honest. What normal human being would want to be part of such a cesspit  As we are all well aware, the past three years have seen a constipated parliament unable, or unwilling, to sort out Brexit, forcing us all into a nightmarish version of Groundhog Day.I believe the idea of a European referendum was the height of stupidity by a spooked David Cameron who wanted to neuter Nigel Farage. When the nation voted Leave, Cameron was the first to abandon ship.Never mind “women and children first”. He was rowing away from a Titanic mess in a leboat stuffed with like-minded, snivelling clowns, leaving poor Theresa May behind playing an out-of-tune piano with the rest of the ship’s doomed orchestra. Mrs May foolishly called an election that was a personal disaster, then was worn down until she had to step aside.Boris Johnson thought he could bluster and blag his way to a solution and promised we would exit the EU a couple of days ago, on Halloween. For all his blather about “dying in a ditch”, he couldn’t deliver.So here we are, facing a pre-Christmas election at a time when distrust of politicians has never been higher and our expectations have been never lower. It is easy to dismiss the whole bloody lot of them as a waste of time.But there ARE some decent MPs who want to make a dference. Sadly, some are unwilling to put up with the scrutiny and vilication the job now entails and many are heading out the door.Female MPs, in particular, have been subjected to online abuse that chills the blood. As well as death threats, they have had to deal with vile monsters threatening rape and other violent attacks. It’s horric to have to cope with such hideous abuse on a daily basis. I can’t blame them for quitting in despair.Their fears are real. We saw that with the tragic murder of MP Jo Cox in . She was a we and mother who wanted to make the world a better place and do the best possible job for her constituents. It’s a real pity the MPs now calling it a day are mainly moderates who were calm ­voices of reason amid all the shrieking and howling from extremists on both sides of the political ide.Heidi Allen, a Tory who joined the Lib Dems, can no longer cope with the “nastiness and intimidation” which has become the norm in Parliament. Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan is leaving because the abuse towards her has had a “clear impact” on her ­family.The Tory and the Labour leaderships should hang their heads in shame at allowing such an appalling situation to develop. They should have called off their attack dogs and clamped down on cowardly online trolls.There have always been robust arguments and passionate debates in politics — but nothing like the sheer hatred and aggression Brexit has unleashed. MPs were used to attacks from opposing parties. But now some of the worst abuse comes from inside.Left-wing extremists threaten deselection for Labour MPs who even whisper about their discontent with Corbyn. Tories find themselves booted out for failing to toe the line. Sadly, the next six weeks will see even more of this aggression as we have to listen to hate-filled rants and ­ludicrous, undeliverable ­promises to secure our votes.It is strange to think that Westminster was respected and admired not so very long ago. I honestly don’t think those days will ever . We deserve so much better.SOME welcome good news comes in the form of Richard and Judy, who will pop back on to our TV screens to front the show they helped make such a huge success.It was meant to be a one-off when they presented This Morning a couple of weeks ago. But viewers were so excited, “R and J” have an open invitation to .The stumbling block has always been because Judy was reluctant toto live national TV. But Richard told me this week she really enjoyed herself and loved reconnecting with This Morning’s loyal audience.Richard was quick to stress that they are not after anyone’s jobs or in the market for a permanent– but it would be lovely to pop in now and again. I’m delighted. They are both total pros who make it all look delightfully easy and relaxed.They also have the sort of public affection only enjoyed by the Queen and Dame Judi Dench.IT is heartbreaking to think Ben Needham would have turned  this week. He has been for ever frozen in time as that little blond toddler playing in the Greek sunshine before going missing on Kos back in .Brave mum Kerry has never once stopped fighting to discover the truth. Three years ago, British police finally conducted a thorough investigation.They believe Ben was killed in an accident involving a digger on a building site on the island, where his grandad worked and close to where the family lived at the time. Despite handing over their evidence to authorities on the island, there have been no further attempts to find Ben’s body.Poor Kerry should have been celebrating her grown-up son’s milestone birthday, perhaps with her daughter-in-law and grandchildren. Instead, her agony ­continues.She has no closure, no grave to visit and is no nearer to finding out exactly what happened to her son almost three decades ago.I CAN’T wait to see what Michelle Visage and Giovanni Pernice have in store for us on Strictly Come Dancing. Last week their Halloween routine was perfection and Michelle foxtrotted around the floor like a gothic goddess.She was my tip to make the final even before the first steps were taken in this year’s competition. I knew Michelle had the sass, talent and work ethic to go all the way. I love that she’s flying the flag for the over-s while exuding buckets of sex appeal.Don’t forget that for years Michelle suffered with a serious autoimmune disease she believes was caused by her breast implants. She has only just recovered from surgery to have them removed.Michelle is a steel magnolia and the best is yet to come. So make sure you give her and Giovanni your vote.A HUGE thank you to everyone who has been so positive about Shine, my book out this week.With my th birthday coming up at the end of this month, it felt like a good time to reflect and take stock. I also wanted to share all of the knowledge and advice I’ve acquired from so many of the guests and experts I’ve met over the  years I’ve been on TV.So I decided to put it all into a book that will hopefully give useful tips and information to make your le better. I want it to be a book you can have by your bedside, to dip into when you need a bit of a confidence boost or advice on looking good and feeling great.I’m doing some signings on Saturday, so do pop in and say hello at WH Smith in Glasgow’s St Enoch Centre at noon and at Waterstones on Princes Street in Edinburgh at pm.I WAS in the US last week, going through astronaut training at Nasa. I will tell you about that very soon. But I also managed a couple of days to recover in Florida’s Key West. My husband and I had no idea that at this time of year there is a little event called Fantasy Fest. Well. What an eye-opener that was.Some brave souls were out and about in nothing more than expertly applied body paint. I was a bit bemused at first and obviously I refrained from joining in.But it is amazing how quickly you get used to someone wearing nothing but a leather posing pouch standing at the bar talking to you about the latest Trump baloney.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: greta thunberg kids terrified
story: Scientists have discovered that around , years ago, a new sort of animal started wandering around in a bit of Africa we now call Botswana. It was called “man”.He was hemmed in on all sides by giant deserts he couldn’t cross because, at this point, God had not invented the Land Rover. But it didn’t matter back then because this part of the world was full of all the food and water the mans and womans would ever need.It was lush, green and beautul. Everyone was very happy. Now, imaginethey’d known the planet was about to wobble on its axis, which would cause us to start on an all-new orbit around the sun.Imagine the panic. Imagine how many Greta Thunbergs would have rampaged about the place, blaming their elders for the mess and the certain death that faced them all. All the usual routes to the ­watering holes and fruit trees would have been blocked by ­activists in weird costumes saying a whole new way of le had to be adopted to stave off disaster.Everyone would have been told to go vegan and stop wearing shoes made from leather. But they didn’t know the Earth was about to wobble. They just woke up one morning to find the climate had changed.It was warmer and wetter. In fact, there was so much rain, the deserts surrounding them came to le. This meant they could explore strange new worlds and boldly go where no one had gone before.They moved to Europe and Asia. They spread out across the seas and soon, they came up with ­literature and agriculture and architecture and medicine. They became civilised and happy and healthy. And then they started going on holidays and drinking beer and laughing on the way home from the pub with their friends and a delicious kebab.And then they got next-day delivery on anything they wanted and a new smartphone every year and Instagram. One day, a tall man with a motoring show on the television was even able to drive a Lancia right across the salt pans where it all began. And all of that was possible thanks to a big, juicy lump of global warming.That’s the thing about climate change. We keep being told the next sht will be a disaster for mankind. But who knows  You might wake up one morning to find your garden full of unicorns and mermaids and big chests full of jewels and money.LOTS of people are wondering why Jeremy Corbyn took so long to agree to an election. But the answer is simple.Corbyn knew the longer he could stall Brexit, the more damage would be done to the one thing he hates more than everything : Britain. He’s always sided with anyone who wants to do us harm. The IRA. Hamas. Russia. You name it.He wants everyone in those camps in Calais to come here because he knows it will destabilise our way of le. In fact, every one of his policies is designed specically to ruin the country.Because that’s what the bitter and twisted weasel wants. Mind you, the Shadow Chancellor is even worse.Which isn’t strictly trueyou’ve got a one-off Ferrari  Speciale MM. APPARENTLY Daniel Craig was fed up with saying: “The name’s Bond. James Bond.” Well, I’m sorry, my precious, but you’re not getting any sympathy here. If you’ve worked in a poultry farm for  years, you can say you’re fed up with chickens.Andyou’ve worked on the railways all your adult le, you can say you are looking forward to a retirement without trains. But you, Mr Craig, only said that line FIVE times. Which is hardly taxing, is it No matter. There’s talk about who will replace him in the role. And because Bond is so woke and #MeToo these days, we cannot rule out the possibility that the role will be given to Diane Abbott or Janet Street-Porter.Some of me hopes he really does die in the new movie, as has been rumoured. Buthe doesn’t, might I suggest the part is given to a chap called Geoffrey Moore, top I met him at a party once and was impressed by his louche, charming style, his clever eyebrow work and his bright orange skin that even David Dickinson would call “over the top”.I’m not sure he can act. But that doesn’t matter because neither could his father Roger . . . and he was the best Bond of them all.BAD news. It seems the plug has been pulled on the hotly anticipated prequel to Game Of Thrones.They had a stellar cast including the brilliant Naomi Watts. And it was being written by Jane Goldman, the brains behind Kick-Ass and Kingsman. And her husband Jonathan Ross.HBO, though, has obviously decided the end result won’t work, which begs a question: How can they know I’ve worked in television for  years butsomeone came to me and said: “We have a show featuring an old lady baking cakes” I’d have put their ideas in a big bag of rubbish, along with that hare-brained scheme to stage a prime-time dancing competition.GATWICK airport is set to roll out a new system to cut boarding times and reduce delays.Sounds clever, yes. But it means you won’t be able to board with your family.And it does nothing to address the main problem: People who board with fridge freezers they’ve bought in duty free and which won’t fit in the overhead lockers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit party votes corbyn no10
story: Nigel Farage will not be Prime Minister. Nor is he remotely likely to hold the balance of power.There is no longer a route to the No Deal Brexit he wants. Nor any prospect of Boris Johnson caving to his demands for a pact, destroying the Tories’ unity. And it is patently untrue to say Boris’s deal is not Brexit. The Tory ERG simply wouldn’t back itso.It will end our membership, payments and free movement and extract us from the customs union and single market, with no “backstop” keeping us half-in. We would trade freely as an independent nation. And Boris alone can get us out. The sole alternative as PM is Corbyn, and he will keep us in the EU for ever.In a few constituencies Farage’s party could hurt Labour more than the Tories. Overall it is FAR more likely to prevent Boris winning the majority which is vital to delivering Brexit and without which it is lost. That is why Farage’s ultimatum to the PM delighted Labour.Two by-elections — in Peterborough and Brecon, both of which the Tories should have won — were gted to Labour and the Lib Dems by Brexit Party votes. On December , those could put Corbyn in Downing Street in a Remain coalition.At which point Farage’s legacy won’t just be that his vanity wrecked his le’s work.That a party he founded with only one aim, a real Brexit, became the very instrument of the project’s destruction.He will be remembered as the right-wing maverick who handed anti-Semitic, anti-Western Marxists an unprecedented chance to plunder the world’s fth-largest economy. The Sun admires Farage.His pressure brought about the referendum AND a better deal. But he could now be the author of a double national catastrophe.He and his voters should think again.WE’VE heard it all now.Labour’s Tom ­Watson, of all people, insists broadcasters must combat the Tories’ “fake news”.That’s the same Tom Watson who destroyed lives spreading a paedophile’s lies.Whose party’s campaign centres on a blatant fiction about Boris “selling the NHS to Trump”.Whose leader lies endlessly about his terrorist sympathies and anti-Semitism — then sinisterly orders reporters: “Just report what we say.”These charlatans lecture journalists about the truth.But they themselves are strangers to it.Andthey took power, Press freedom would be a nostalgic memory.The Sun joins everyone rooting for Owen and England’s rugby heroes.Best of ruck, lads!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris centre of attention may
story: “I feel confident, but then I felt confident in ,” one leading Cabinet Minister tells me.There is a Tory fear that ­history could repeat itself — that Jeremy Corbyn could surge again and an election designed to deliver a majority for Brexit could once more lead to a hung Parliament. But oddly,  is one of the things that mean the Tories might win that majority this time round. They are determined not to make the same mistakes again. As one senior party figure puts it: “We screwed it up once. We’re not going to do that again.”When Chancellor Sajid Javid spoke to Tory MPs on Wednesday night, he reassured them that “this campaign will not be like last time”. He described Theresa May’s  effort as “the most incompetent election campaign in modern times”.In , the Tories assumed that their chunky poll lead would easily translate into a big majority. There was a complacency and cockiness about their campaign. There was no ­rationale for why Mrs May was going back on her pledge not to have an election and a belief that the Tories could use that lead to win a mandate for almost anything.This time round, the Tories are being much more cautious. The groundwork has been laid for this campaign. Conservative Campaign HQ has been getting election-ready for months. The Tories have heavy-hitters ready to join their ­campaign team, including Paul Stephenson, one of the key ­figures from Vote Leave’s  victory. In , Mrs May took her own party machine by ­surprise with her decision to go to the country.In another dference with the ex-PM, Boris Johnson has a clear argument for why an ­election is needed — the only thing this Parliament is capable of on Brexit is delay. It is hard to see how anyone who wants Brexit and has seen what has happened since the  election could disagree with that.This Tory desire not to screw up will also lead to more ­discipline. This time, the ­manesto will be a cautious document, not an attempt to gain a mandate for a series of deeply unpopular reforms. The fact that everyone knows this election will be close helps the Tories too. There’ll be much more scrutiny of what a Corbyn premiership would mean than there was in .Cabinet Ministers believe that the prospect of a Labour SNP deal which would see Nicola Sturgeon’s Scottish Nationalists help Corbyn into Downing Street in exchange for another independence referendum is already cutting through, and particularly in Scotland, where the Tories are increasingly ­confident they can limit their losses to five seats or fewer.But perhaps the biggest dference from  is between Johnson and May. May had never done a ­national campaign before, she disliked big events and preferred going door to door. Boris, by contrast, is a showman who has already ­successfully fronted one nationwide effort, the  referendum. Boris knows how to make himself the centre of attention in a way Mrs May never did.As one Cabinet minister puts it: “Boris is ­capable of stealing the oxygen from all the other candidates.”The most signicant threat to the Tories is pro-Remain tactical voting. The big question, frets one Cabinet minister, is whether Labour and the Lib Dems end up splitting the ­centre-left vote and letting the Tories win — as happened with Labour and the SDP in  — or whether there is anti-Tory voting that condemns scores of previously safe Tory MPs to defeat — as happened in .Butthe Tories avoid the pitfalls of , then even from a much less promising starting position they should be able to win a majority.THIS election will see the first ever head-to-head televised leaders’ debate between the two big parties. On November , Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson will clash in primetime on ITV. Both Labour and the Tories think they will benefit from this one-on-one format.On the Labour side, they hope that it helps them unite the anti-Tory vote behind Corbyn. The Tories think the question of who you want to be Prime Minister – Johnson or Corbyn – favours them.During the  campaign, Theresa May lost her lead on this question. But right now, Boris Johnson has a -point advantage over Corbyn. If he can maintain anything like this margin, he’ll still be in No  come Christmas.Downing Street also thinks that making this election a forced choice between a Tory government and a Labour government works to their benefit. title: boris must convince tory virgins
story: My mum was old-school tribal Labour, a militant dinner lady, always happy to go on strike when her union asked, at home on the picket line, her lelong allegiance to the Labour Party as unchanging as the colour of her eyes.My dad had no love for the Labour Party — he was a corner-shop greengrocer who believed Labour only cared about their militant brothers in the big unions — but Dad despised the Tories with a passion, seeing them as the protectors of big business, rich bosses and inherited privilege.There were plenty of Tory Prime Ministers in Downing Street when I was growing up. But they never got one vote from our house. And I have been thinking of my parents over the past few days and wondering: Would they have broken the habit of a letime and voted for Boris Johnson Because that is the key to who wins this General Election. We hear a lot about how Boris has to woo “Workington Man” — “an older, white, non-graduate male from the north of England with an interest in rugby league and a tendency to vote Labour”. But it is not just Workington Man who holds the keys to  Downing Street now.From one end of the country to the other, it is all those voters such as my mum and dad, who never voted Tory before. That is who Boris has to woo and win. Those millions of Tory virgins.The polls all suggest there is a massive majority for parties which favour leaving the European Union. Butthat vote is split between the Tories and Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party, then we don’t get Brexit.We get Jeremy Corbyn gurning on the steps of No. We get an economy in ruins. We get Venezuela without the nice weather.  But splitting the Leave vote is not a strategy for delivering Brexit. It is a cast-iron guarantee that Brexit is cancelled. If you want to see the result of the Referendum, you have to vote Tory.My mum and dad would not have recognised the rotten Labour Party of today. They would have been baffled, then angered, by the total absence of anything resembling patriotism among Corbyn and his Marxist mob.My parents would have scratched their heads at Labour’s immigration policy — to allow “as much free movement as possible” — not because they disliked foreigners but because they thought the identity of their country was worth preserving.My folks would never have trusted a grizzled old Marxist like John McDonnell with their hard-earned wages. They would have been wary of seeing the police force supervised by Diane Abbott.They would have noted Emily Thornberry sneering at the flag of St George while happily adorning herself in the EU flag. They would not understand how Corbyn could happily lick the sandals of Hamas, Hezbollah and the IRA.My parents — the kind of people who fought our wars, paid their taxes for a letime and built this country up from the rubble — would not have spat on this Labour Party. And after years of seeing Parliament place itself above the people, they would have crawled across broken glass to get to the polling booth on December .My parents believed in democracy. They had no doubts about the importance of voting. They would never have voted for Jeremy Corbyn. But would they have seen that the Conservative Party is now their natural home That’s your historic task now, Boris — convince the millions of working-class patriots like my mum and dad that you truly understand their lives. Andyou can do that, you will win a landslide.We have heard a lot about the failure of fire chiefs and their policy of “stay put” which added to the death toll of .But there has not been nearly enough focus on the heroism of the firefighters who were there on that hellish night.Firefighters put their lives on the line for strangers.Yes, that is their job. But their job deserves our unequivocal respect and gratitude.PRESENTER Samira Ahmed is suing her employers at the BBC for £, in pay because she received a fraction of what Jeremy Vine was paid for allegedly “similar” work.I like Samira Ahmed on Newswatch and wish her well.But Jeremy Vine is far more of a household name. And when it comes to getting paid, star power matters more than gender.I would like to be banking the same royalty cheques for my books as JK Rowling. But best not to hold my breath.IN the Eighties I did a story on the politan Police’s Vice Squad, which logged the contents of the pornographic videos they seized while watching the raunchy action in fast-forward.I can still recall the bored, joyless expressions of the young Vice Squad coppers as they yawned through all that fast-forwarded filth.Now Netflix is offering the same sort of thing – aallowing viewers to watch shows at up to one-and-a-half times the normal speed. Don’t bother.If it’s not worth watching in real time, it’s not worth watching at all.THERE are million dog owners in the UK and I can’t have been the only one who cringed to hear President Trump boasting that IS monster Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi had “died like a dog”. And exactly how does a dog die, Mr President In my experience, a dog dies surrounded by humans who feel as though they have just had their heart torn out. A dog dies surrounded by love. A dog dies bitterly mourned by the family it leaves behind.According to Trump, the IS leader, “whimpered, cried and screamed like a coward . . . in utter fear, panic and dread”. My dog is not going out of this world like that. When our Stan finally goes, many years from now, he will be in my arms and looking in my eyes.Death will be painless and peaceful. It will be a moment of love and grief. Who writes your lousy material, Donald  All this “dying like a dog” rubbish felt stupidly off-the-cuff.While the world is mightily glad to see the back of a mass murderer, the florid violence of Donald Trump’s language sounded exactly like the kind of crass rhetoric we hear from terrorists.The President’s sneering “died like a dog” line was particularly misjudged because American special forces were helped in their ultra-dangerous mission by military search dogs.They pursued al-Baghdadi right up to the moment he detonated his suicide vest, injuring one of the brave dogs – a Belgian Malinois named Conan – who will be honoured at the White House next week.Kill all the terrorists you like, Mr President. But there is really no need to talk like one.THE traditional Guy Fawkes Night celebrations of my childhood have largely been replaced by Halloween.This makes me incredibly sad, although my we says Halloween is far less dangerous than all the bonfires and bangers of my boyhood.But did you see this outfit Craig Revel Horwood sported on Halloween ROBBIE WILLIAMS, , has challenged Liam Gallagher, , to a boxing match.Really not recommended at their age. How long is it since Britpop   years Stick to a game of draughts, Robbie.I WAS forced to play rugby at school and always hated it.But I have fallen in love with the sport at this glorious World Cup in Japan.But North kept running – or hobbling – and STILL made the tackle.I do hope our soft Premier League footballers have been watching.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: john legend baby its cold outside peak woke
story: Granted, anything that celebrates a man trying to ply a woman with booze in order to persuade her to stay the night sounds all wrong in . Happily, though, most of us know that, these days, coercion and force in the bedroom are not only ­unromantic but unacceptable.The offending lyrics in the song, which is a duet, are uttered by the female voice, which sings: “I simply must go, the answer is no” . . . only for the man she is singing to to hand her a drink — and for her to question what is in it. Obviously not good on any level. But this song was written in  .It was a hit during a time when sex was for marriage, and women weren’t actually allowed to express any active interest in men so had to feign modesty at all times. In the s and s, before the Pill was introduced, that dance of reluctance and “persuasion” was part of the courting process and the whole process of seduction was based on women pretending they weren’t interested only to be ­persuaded that they were.But look how dferent things are now.Also, let’s face it, when you get the magnying glass out, there are plenty of storylines from the past that don’t quite measure up to the standards of . Look at James Bond, who basically sexually assaults Honor Blackman’s ­character Pussy Galorein the movie Goldfinger.Or the song Every Breath You Take and the film Love Actually, both of which feature a stalker as the romantic lead. And when you think about it, Daniel Cleaver’s courting of Bridget Jones really just boils down to ­sexual harassment.There are countless other examples of “romantic” plots which are very dodgy indeed by current standards but, at the time, we all lapped them up. And don’t even get me started on the lyrics of rap songs that are being played today which routinely talk about killing and raping women. Now that is grim.But instead of allowing this song to exist as the relic from the past, soul singer John Legend and Kelly Clarkson have rewritten it. Their version now includes the lines, “What will my friends think If I have one more drink  ”.That is instead of “The neighbours might think,   Say what’s in this drink  .  Legend describes his version as having “a new-found sensitivity in the #MeToo era”. I’d put it a dferent way and say he is ­trying to re-write history.Last year a radio station in Ohio announced it would stop playing the original because of ­complaints from listeners saying the song, “didn’t have a place in modern music”. That’s fine. No one needs to play itpeople are offended by it. But the idea that we can airbrush the fact that it existed in the first place is ridiculous and I worry we are all in danger of trying too hard to be PC.The risk is we become so vanilla, so afraid of upsetting everyone with our view, that we stop speaking our mind, which is a form of societal repression. Yes, it’s good to stand up for what you believe in, but taking offence at the lyrics of a song more than  years old might not be the best cause to bat for.Everything has a context, andwe aren’t careful we will all be so worried about how “woke” we are that we will forget our own views and how to express them.PARENTS everywhere will be reassured to learn that even when you are a sporting hero your kids still think you are a bit of an embarrassment.Peter Crouch said in an interview yesterday that his daughter, Sophia, who is eight, initially asked him to stay outside when he dropped her off at summer camp – because the other kids were laughing about how tall he is .The thing is, as any parent will confirm,it wasn’t his height she would have found another reason that he had to stay outside, whether it be his shoes, coat or haircut.In fact, don’t worry Peter, as they get older they get embarrassed about you just for breathing.MILLIONS of motorists use their mobile phones while they drive. Thirty-five per cent of drivers under the age of , and  per cent of all drivers, admitted to taking their eyes off the road to check texts, email or social media, an RAC survey reports.But the current law means reckless drivers can only be prosecutedthey are caught using hand-held phones to call or text. Meanwhile, those who take photos or scroll through music playlists are exempt from punishment.So police have struggled to enforce the law because they are often unable to prove exactly what drivers are using their phones for. Bear in mind thata driver looks at their phone for just two seconds while travelling at mph, they will cover ft blind, drastically increasing their chance of an accident.So I’m fully behind plans for a ban on even touching a mobile phone while driving, which were announced – drivers take note – on Friday. It is thought the ban could be in place by spring next year.Drivers caught holding phones to browse social media, or even input a sat-nav location, now face six points and a fine of up to £. But how anyone can be complacent enough to check Insta while in charge of a moving metal box that can kill people is beyond me.I have not driven for ten years – I walk or get the Tube – but my kids do and it really bothers methey even so much as glance at their phones. There is no doubt that it is distracting – and dangerous for the driver, but also to others. So this proposed new law is nothing but a good thing as far as I’m concerned.I’VE never been one to embrace dressing up for Halloween or any other kind of forced fun.Sorryyou think that makes me sound like a killjoy, but one thing I have noticed with each passing year is the sexualising of Halloween going off the scales.Forget wizards, goblins and ghouls – every celebrity event seems to be populated only with sexy vampires, sexy ghosts and sexy witches. Witness Heidi Klum’s Frankenstein costume at her annual Halloween party in New York this week.The dress code seems to be wear what you like as long as it’s thigh-high, PVC or a bikini – with some fake blood. Dressing up should be banned – I haven’t done it since I was seven.ENGLAND’S poor rugby team. Yesterday they lost in the final of the World Cup after being fined for their response to the Kiwi pre-match Haka in the semi-final.Owen Farrell and Co stood in a “V” formation while the Haka went on. But it turns out they were supposed to remain in their own half, and some players didn’t.New Zealand’s Haka is all about intimidating the opposition. But the opposition are not allowed to respond The Haka is a dance about cutting off people’s heads.But it was England’s harmless response of standing still and forming a V for Victory – which I thought was brilliant – that was reprimanded.MY goodness, Rosie Huntington- Whiteley looks utterly gorgeous in her underwear.MS using her as a model is possibly its best marketing decision ever.You only have to look at her wearing nothing but white lace to think thatyou buy the same set, some of her beauty might rub off on you.I loved the comment from Cheryl Tweedy in response to Rosie’s Insta post: “And where do we get that body ”Nowonly that, too, was available to buy from MS.LOVED reading the stories this week from Angela Kelly, who dressed the Queen for  years.I particularly liked how she helped to avoid disaster at the  Commonwealth Games in Kuala Lumpur after the Queen’s hat arrived at the last minute. Her Majesty had been due to wear the hat as she officially closed the games but was distraught to find that it was unsuitable.I wouldn’t normally bother reading tittle-tattle stories about the Queen, but knowing that she has consented for them to be told I am really enjoying them.Also, the closest this great lady has got to making a mistake in  years is to wear her hat the wrong way round . . . which speaks volumes about her, doesn’t it Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: A crudely glorious image, painted yesterday by BoJo’s ex-mayoral aide Katie Perrior, sums up the extraordinary reach this Old Etonian posh boy has into the hearts of ­Britain’s working classes.It explains why Labour MPs are petried by the threat to their careers from millions of Leave-voting voters snubbed by the metropolitan elite.With poll leads up to  per cent, sky-high personal ratings and an overwhelming desire to see Brexit done, this is an election Boris Johnson should win by a landslide.We can surely count on the sound common sense of the British people to save us from anti-Semitic left-wing revolutionary Jeremy Corbyn.Yes, but . . .  Theresa May taught us the hard way about jumping to conclusions.All elections are perilous. title: can you spot the 25 best things about britain in this mind boggling puzzle
story: Hidden away in this quintessentially British scene are  of the best things about a truly Great Britain.The most wonderful things about our country were revealed from a study of , UK adults, which also found eight in  are proud of their heritage.Readers will find an average of  clues before giving in to peek at the answers, and of those who successfully complete the puzzle they take an for yourself, and see how you fare against our fair nation.Despite not being featured in the challenging brainteaser, the research also found bacon cooked ‘right’, being able to put anything in a title: ghost tv house edinburgh faith peden
story: Faith Peden, , said she didn’t spot his reflection when she photographed the previous owner’s TV centre.But when she showed mates the pic they pointed him out — sending shivers down her spine.She said: “I’ve never believed in ghosts before but there is just no logic to this. I can’t get my head around it.”Estate agent Faith took the picture of the telly and DVD unit in her second floor flat in Broughton, Edinburgh as she wanted to flog it online.She continued: “I showed it to my friends that night and asked them how much they’d reckon I’d get for the centre.“But I was stunned when they asked, ‘Who’s your old mate ’“I had no idea what they were going on about, so looked at the picture again.“You can clearly see him with his white hair and glasses looking to the side.You can even see what he is wearing — a white shirt and dark cardigan I’d never seen him in my le.I was totally freaked out. I was in the flat alone and there’s no way it could be a reflection from someone in the street.”Faith has called for help to identy the spook — who she reckons is a benign presence.Though she’s a supernatural sceptic she added: “My friend’s mum is very spiritual so I asked her round for an opinion.“She told me the man had been trapped there for ten years and I had released him, so maybe I’m a real-le ghostbuster.We’ve called him Bob. I’m not afraid as I keep telling myself he is a friendly ghost.”Faith pleaded for anyone who may be able to explain the image to come forward.As this is my new home, I’m hoping it is just a technological glitch.”

title: 18th century manor hotel on sale for 1 5m
story: The luxurious Boscundle Manor in Cornwall was originally built for the captain of a tin mine and it is surrounded by . acres of attractive landscaped gardens.The manor, which is listed by Lillicrap Chilcott for £.m, is located in Tregrehan near St Austell and boasts a spa and restaurant.Explaining its history, the selling agent said: “Boscundle Manor is believed to date from the mid-s and was originally a mine captain’s house constructed for the captain of the Wheal Eliza Consoles mine, one of the most prosperous tin mines in Cornwall.”The property has been refurbished by the current owners who have created a hotel with  luxurious letting suites and communal areas including a lounge, restaurant, a conservatory and a superb indoor heated swimming pool with adjacent hot tub and spa room.The selling agents added: “This superb venue has alcohol and wedding licences and is a perfect venue for a marquee event with a croquet lawn and thatched gazebo, licences for civil ceremonies.The hotel has a loyal staff base so it could be bought by a hotelier or manager but it could alsoto a private residence with the necessary planning consents.

title: harry dunn demand truth anne sacoolas leave uk
story: Harry was just -years-old when a car was claimed to have been driven on wrong side of the road - colliding with his motorbike and killing him outside RAF Croughton in Northamptonshire in August.But suspect Anne Sacoolas, , claimed diplomatic immunity and fled back to the US before she could be quizzed by UK cops over causing death by dangerous driving.Speaking on Good Morning Britain today, grieving dad Tim Dunn said they knew the tragic night had been an accident but still needed answers.He said: We want the truth of why this lady was allowed to leave.Since the crash, Northamptonshire Police interviewed suspect Ms Sacoolas over just what happened on the tragic day in August.They have since passed the evidence onto the CPS.But Harrys family said they had no ideaand when charges would be brought.Speaking today on the Victoria Derbyshire show, dad Tim added: I can’t see how charges won’t be brought, with the evidence against her.It would be ludicrous to not bring charges with the evidence there - it’s for all to see.They said they hoped thatMs Sacoolas was charged, she would be extradited back to face court.Since Ms Sacoolas left the UK, it was claimed she did not have diplomatic immunity.The parents had earlier this year travelled to America to speak with authorities there - meeting with US President Donald Trump.But they said they had been shocked when they were told Ms Sacoolas was in the other room at the White House.Mum Charlotte Charles said the meeting had been sprung on them.The family ultimately chose not to speak with her, saying they wanted to have a proper meeting that involved mediators and therapists.They are now set to launch civil proceedings against the American.The family is set to refer Northamptonshire Police to the Independent Office for Police Conduct over their handling of the investigation.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman married ghost 300 year depp
story: Amanda Large, , married ghost Jack Teague at sea within two years of meeting him.But she says the spook made her physically ill and she had to perform an exorcism to get rid of his malevolent spirit.Now she also wants to get rid of anything that reminds her of Jack - including a picture of him she bought five years ago.Amanda said: After the exorcism a lot of the stuff was burned but I couldnt bring myself to burn or get rid of the painting, its definitely haunted.Ive moved on and I know especially at this time of the year some people collect such items so rather than just destroy it I would rather it go to someone who wants it.Amanda from Drogheda, Co Louth, but living in Downpatrick, ‘met’ Jack in  when his apparition appeared beside her in bed.She was immediately taken with the spook, who she claims looks like Pirates of the Caribbean character Jack Sparrow, played by Johnny Depp.Jack, a Haitian pirate from the s was executed for being a thief on the high seas.He began appearing regularly before Amanda  realised she fancied him and they began having sex.After two years of dating, Amanda told him she wanted commitment and he agreed to marry her.In , Amanda hired a registrar and sailed into international waters so she could legally marry him - using a spiritual medium to allow him to say I do during the ceremony.However, after two years of marriage Amanda started suffering from health problems and started to get recurring abscesses.After three weeks, the sores got so bad that Amanda had to be rushed to hospital for surgery.In May  she developed sepsis.She said: I almost died and I was in the hospital for a week.But Amanda says her spooky partner tried to kill her when she ended their relationship.She underwent an exorcism in December  after Jack possessed her.The painting is being kept in a store room by Amanda as she fears having it too near her.When you look at this painting, it has eyes that seem to follow you around the room and you do get a chill up your spine when you look at it.Amanda has put the item up for sale Ebay and hopes to raise £ for local animal rescue charities.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The frantic family of Stephanie Parze have told police she mysteriously vanished just  minutes away from her home in New Jersey.The -year-old and a few of her female relatives went to see the medium on Wednesday night, dad Edward Parze told reporters.From there, she went to her grandmother’s home where she has been living since her granddad died.The next morning her family grew increasingly concerned they hadn’t heard from her, reports the New York Post.When they showed up at the home her car was parked in the driveway but she was nowhere to be found.“We just want to find her,” her father added.  “She’s not the type of person who wouldn’t text, ‘Hey mom, I’m on my way to work.Worried mum Sharlene Parze added she found her daughter’s cell phone with a text message from a family member whose children she was supposed to be looking after.“She would never go out of the house without her phone,” she told News  New Jersey.“ Everything is just not her. title: lindsay hoyle new speaker odds
story: Heres what we know about the seasoned politician and why he could be taking John Bercows empty seat.Sir Lindsay Hoyle is a Labour politician who has served as an MP for Chorley, Lancs, since .He was born on June , , in Adlington, where he continues to live and work.His father was Labour MP Doug Hoyle, who named him after Australian batsman Lindsay Hassett.The current odds on him being the favourite are at   at William Hill.Sir Lindsay is the most senior of departing speaker Bercows three deputies, and also works as Chairman of Ways and Means.He was elected as Deputy Speaker of the House in a secret ballot on June .This means he has had some serious practice in the Speakers chair - deputising for two or three hours every day.He is popular on both sides of the House and wants to position himself as the stable choice in unpredictable times.Hoyle is known for clashing with former PM Tony Blair over Gibraltar and student tuition fees.He has said of their dferences: Im not anti-Tony he made us electable and won three times. But there are principles and promises you dont break.Hoyle is known to be softly spoken, in contrast to the belligerent Bercow.He has vowed to tame the bear pit of a toxic Parliamentelected to the role, telling the Sunday Times he would crack down on aggressive language.Hoyle has never declared his views on Brexit.Hoyle has been married twice and had two daughters.Sir Lindsay Hoyle married his first we, Lynda Anne Fowler, in .They later orced and Mr Hoyle went on to marry Catherine Swindley in . They celebrated their silver wedding anniversary last year.One of his daughters, Natalie Lewis-Hoyle, tragically took her own le at the age of .Her mother, Miriam Lewis, said Natalie had been in a toxic and troubled relationship before her death in .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mcdonalds boss steve easterbrook naughty boy
story: The fast food giant said chief executive Steve Easterbrook, , who was paid £ million last year, had demonstrated poor judgement.McDonalds forbids bosses from having consensual romantic relationships with subordinates, regardless of whether they directly manage them.Watford-born Easterbrook is orced from ex-we Susie and has three children.His brother-in-law Mark Baxter, , told the MailOnline: “Looks like Steve has been a naughty boy.“We heard on Sunday that he had been fired. We don’t know any other details. My we keeps in contact but we have not seen him for a while.”Mr Baxter is married to Easterbrook’s sister Joanne and owns a -acre farm near Berkhamsted in Hertfordshire.He said the former McDonalds boss orced in , around the time he moved to America to become the companys CEO.In an email to employees, Easterbrook acknowledged he had a relationship with an employee and said it was a mistake.Given the values of the company, I agree with the board that it is time for me to move on, he said.Easterbrook joined McDonalds in  as a manager in London and worked his way up through the ranks of the company.He left to become the boss of Pizza Express in  and then Wagamama before ing to McDonalds in  after which he became the global boss of the company.Scrutiny of executives and their treatment of employees has intensied amid the #MeToo movement, which highlighted sexual harassment in the workplace and abuse of power by male executives.In June , Intel boss Brian Krzanich resigned after he had a consensual relationship with an employee that breached company policy.According to Carl Tobias, a law professor at the University of Richmond, Easterbrooks sacking is sign of the influence of MeToo#.Other companies dont always act on that kind of information or fire their CEO for that, and so it seems like they trying to enforce a pretty strict policy in this situation, he said.McDonalds has itself faced sexual harassment charges and in May said it was enhancing training and offering a new hotline, after workers filed dozens of complaints against the company.Fight for , the group which filed the charges, said McDonalds response to its sexual harassment complaints has been inadequate, and the company needs to be completely transparent about Easterbrooks firing and any other executive departures related to these issues.McDonalds board of directors decided on Easterbrooks departure on Friday and details of his severance package will be released today.Under his leadership the companys shares nearly doubled in value while sales at its US restaurants stagnated.The board of directors named Chris Kempczinski, who joined the company in  and recently served as president of title: new speaker to be revealed today
story: Seven candidates are bidding to take on the role following Mr Bercows departure with Labour MP Sir Lindsay Hoyle the bookies favourite.Mother of the House Harriet Harman - the current longest continuously serving female MP – is also predicted to do well.The other four candidates are Dame Rosie Winterton and Dame Eleanor Laing, who also both served as Mr Bercows deputies, Labours Meg Hillier and Chris Bryant , plus Conservative Sir Edward Leigh.Shailesh Vara and Sir Henry Bellingham have both withdrawn from contention.Candidates submitted their written nominations this morning with their signed declarations needing to be supported by between  and  MPs.The Commons will meet as normal at .pm and each candidate will give a speech - the order decided by drawing lots.A secret ballot among MPs will take place once the speeches have concluded.Ken Clarke opened proceedings and invited MPs to keep their speeches short - much to cheers in the Chamber.Dame Rosie was the first to speak and told the House that as Speaker she would douse the flames - not put petrol on them.She also added that the Speaker should change the tone and lower the temperature when it gets heated.Chris Bryant said it is important the chamber “revitalises” parliamentary democracy and “s to the rule book”.Mr Bryant added that a good Speaker should be an “umpire not a player”.Sir Edward Leigh told MPs that the House should be “proud” of what it has achieved in the past three years - rather than argue over the Brexit impasse.The veteran Tory backbencher also said thathe becomes Speaker he would “encourage” back-benchers who “hold the government to account”.Dame Eleanor Laing said thatvoted to the chair she would have the courage to defend members of Parliament not just inside this house but outside as well.”She also said that MPs need to “rebuild confidence in trust in our politics”.Meg Hillier told MPs “I’ve got your back” in her speech to be Speaker.She also reassured the chamber “I would not seek self publicity but speak up only for MPs and Parliament in our democracy.Sir Lindsay Hoyle saidhe became Speaker he would ensure there is “no pecking order”.The bookies’ favourite said “we’re all equal in this House when we speak.”While Harriet Harman vowed to appoint a fourth deputy from the minority partiesshe becomes Speaker.The Mother of the House told the chamber: “I would want a fourth deputy in my team drawn from members of minority parties so I would have that perspective right by my side.”MPs can only vote for one candidate and the result will be announced in the chamber.Any candidate who receives more than  per cent of the votes will be proposed to the House as Speaker, although MPs will be asked to vote againno candidate meets the threshold.In the second round of voting, candidates who either came last or received fewer than % of the votes will not be on the ballot paper.There is also a -minute period after each round for candidates to withdraw.Ballots will continue until either one MP wins more than  per cent of the votes or only one remains.A motion is then put to the Commons proposing the winner as Speaker and they will take the chairthis is agreed. If not, a vote takes place.Speeches of congratulation are expected to follow the votes.Mr Bercow departed the Speakers chair on October .The -year-old entered Parliament in  and held several shadow ministerial positions before taking the Speakers chair on June  , promising to serve no more than nine years in total.In recent months he also come under fire for a series of controversial Brexit rulings in the chamber which were widely considered to favour Remain supporters.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe near £billion wasted on vanity projects when Boris Johnson was Mayor of London is loose change compared to the bill for his failing Premiership. The £million unbuilt aposluvvieapos garden bridge, illegal water cannons, narcissistic buses, the conceited Boris Island airport plan in the Thames that never took off and an expensive Taxpayers’ Stadium for West Ham United’s owners – who just happened to donate cash to the Conservative Party – were bad enough. But they are pennies compared with the pounds his party has cost the country, with their austerity programme – which has cut the economy, squeezed wages, destroyed public services and killed thousands of people – and now Brexit. The Treasury refuses to estimate the financial damage of Johnson’s Brexit bomb only because Chancellor Sajid Javid knows it is disastrous.    Experts at the respected NIESR think tank have calculated it would cost each of us £, within a decade by slashing £billion, or %, off the economy creating a Wales-sized hole. That’s on top of £billion thrown away on No Deal preparations – including a shipless ferry company – and £million on pointless October  virtual propaganda. His moronic “Get Brexit Done” mantra is as  as his Halloween promise to leave. The Tory quack knows a year, maybe years, of renegotiating how we live with Europe follows any orce from the bloc. Jeremy Corbyn delivers a big Brexit speech today in Essex in a smart move to address the issue. He can then focus an election fight on general issues such as wages, jobs, health, education and crime. Britain’s future in or out of Europe requires a fresh referendum, which Corbyn is offering, while Johnson wants to talk only about Brexit.

That includes when it becomes uncomfortable, unpalatable or personally inconvenient.So when the Conservatives promised to maintain free TV licences for the over-s in the  general election , there were no caveats or get-out clauses it seemed a straight pledge that millions of pensioners took at face value.But they reckoned without the sneakiness of the Tories, seeking to evade responsibility for their own commitments. Secondly, he has repeatedly tried to blame the BBC for Conservatives breaking a manesto pledge. Labour, which introduced free licences in , has seized on the Tory betrayal and campaigned, along with the Mirror and pensioner groups, to save them.Today, we exclusively reveal how the party will step in and reverse the Conservativesapos U-turn, safeguarding the vital leline .Deputy Leader Tom Watson is unequivocal in his pledge: “Our message is clear, vote Labour to save free TV licences. title: modern guy fawkes parliament
story: NewsopinionWhat would we make of a modern day Guy Fawkeswe bumped into him under Parliament  years ago, a war veteran angered by broken promises stood in the undercroft of the Houses of Parliament with  barrels of gunpowderShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailImagine you find an Afghanistan war veteran with a bomb under the Houses of Parliament. It’s just you, him, and the bomb, and you chat to him so you can buy some time in which you hope someone will come along, call the police, do the decent thing. So you talk to the soldier. There are lots of things he could be angry about with the people currently sitting above you – electoral fraud, using the NHS as a weapon, Brexiters campaigning against Brexit, Remainers who canapost agree on remaining – but the thing he is livid about is the Armed Forces Covenant. Not the idea of it, which is to ensure military personnel suffer no disadvantage due to their service, and sometimes get preferential treatment because of it. Nor the way it was enshrined in law in  with much fanfare, and the then-Prime Minister promising to “treat people with the dignity they deserve”.    No, he’s angry about the fact that within a year of it being made law, Parliament pissed on it. He’s angry that war veterans like him were made redundant just days before they qualied for a pension, while politicians facing reform to their own pensions got a higher salary to make up for it. Heaposs angry that veterans already investigated and exonerated of war crimes face being investigated again, even when no fresh evidence has been produced, and despite official promises it would stop. And heaposs furious that the veterans who gave their lives and their health for Queen and country - and in some cases, that of their wives and children as well - are still being ignored. Survivors of Cold War radiation experiments have been told evidence of their genetic damage is inconclusive that they must prove an injury sustained  years ago and that, eventhey do, they might be asked to prove it a second time.    Heaposs angry that ex-forces people still face barriers in finding jobs, homes, and mental health support. A study last year showed , veterans had psychological problems, , were in prison, and another , had no permanent address. He knows that everyone suffered in the past decade of cuts to public services. But he points out that those who are more in need of them always suffer most, and that only half of veterans who need that help ever ask for it. Heaposs particularly angry about the current governmentaposs commitment to the covenant, and the debt of honour it represents. He remarks bitterly that theyaposve finally signed it,  years on, and all that means is that the Tory party is now eligible for an employer recognition award. Oh, and theyaposve updated the the website.    Heaposs angry at the state of military housing,  years after the government said selling it off was a grand idea. Heaposs furious at the way his family had to go on a council waiting list. At how,they rent privately, a grasping landlord will rack up the rent for a building unfit for human habitation while their benefit is slashed. At how politicians call people who have to live in those homes scroungers, and say they should be put down. Heaposs angry at a Defence Select Committee report which said the Ministry of Defence was immoral and incompetent, and at a minimum income requirement for immigrants which blocks Commonwealth soldiers settling in the country they shed blood for. He quotes the committee chairman, who said: Every year we take evidence on the implementation of the Armed Forces Covenant, and every year we report similar complaints. The Government is failing in its moral obligation towards those who serve or have served in our armed forces. Heaposs angry about his mates killed for want of proper equipment, at a private defence industry quite literally make a killing with state-funded trips to dictatorial regimes, and heaposs angry at mealy-mouthed letters from politicians thanking him for his service and telling him thereaposs nothing they can do. He says politicians stand with the armed forces when it suits them, but turn their backs when it costs.    As he talks you realise youaposre angry, too. Youaposre angry about a Parliament that stopped governing in the nationaposs interest, and spent  years arguing over a thing that could not be done, purely because theyaposd staked their careers on it. Youaposre angry about allies who behave like enemies, knighthoods for men who hit women, a vice-admiral who consorted with a paedophile rapist yet keeps his pension, and his rank. Youaposre angry that because the people who took it upon themselves to run the country are unable to do so, youaposve been asked to re-elect Islamophobes, anti-Semites, incompetents and rabble-rousers so they can have another go at cocking things up, on a starting salary of £, a year.    You donapost like politicians pitting you against your neighbours because of how they pray or the colour of their skin. Youaposre perplexed about schools that have to shut down one day a week, about a NHS winter crisis that lasts all year, about a minimum wage which isnapost enough to live on. You thought all that crap was supposed to be over, by now. You remember how you were promised electoral reform in  and it never materialised. You wonder about the worth of a system that tells the critically ill to get up and work. You wonder how disabled people can have a better le without the allowances they need to pay for independent living.You realise that many veterans are disabled. And they are given the same crappy treatment as everyone , and often have to fight harder to be compensated by the employer who put them in harmaposs way.    You think about at your local postmaster, corner shop owner, launderette, binman, cabbie, cleaner, nurse, teaching assistant, council operative and heaven knows who  and wonder how, precisely, we’ll manage without migrants, and whoaposll be coming up with the points-based system youaposre told is such a great idea. Perhaps you look at your own bloodline. Perhaps you look at the history books. Perhaps, in the words of those who talk of sedition, treachery and surrender, you hear the echoes of bad people from bad times. You think about the fact .million people who could vote last time didn’t bother. You remind yourself thereaposs more than a million people missing from the electoral register - who should be on it, could be on it, but donapost see the point. You stand there, feeling angry, and think about how  years ago a war veteran with  yearsapos fighting behind him, who worshipped the same God in a dferent way, who felt oppressed and angry about promises his rulers had made and broken, stood in the undercroft of the Houses of Parliament with  barrels of gunpowder, some coal and firewood, and matches in his pocket.    You think about how that veteran was seized and dragged before the king, how he and his fellow plotters were tortured with the rack and other instruments for  weeks to produce confessions, and how after a show trial they were taken to the yard outside Parliament so the politicians could watch as they were hung by the neck, cut down while still alive, castrated, disembowelled, and cut into pieces. Perhaps you know enough to remember that despite injuries so bad he could barely sign his own confession, Guy Fawkes was brave and quick enough to jump from the scaffold before the executioner could stop him, breaking his own neck and saving himself the extra agonies the state wanted to inflict. You wonder why we still celebrate the capture, torture and death of that man with a bonfire and fireworks, why we have forgotten that it was once laid down in law we had to do so whether we agreed or not, and that for centuries his desperation was used to persecute others who shared his faith.    You wonder how we all forgot why he was so angry, or that after he was gone the oppression for people like him simply got worse, and lasted for more than  years. You remind yourself we live in a country where Catholics were banned from marrying senior Royals until , all because Henry VIII took against them. Perhaps youaposd also wonder what the authorities would do to that Afghanistan veteranhe was caught red-handed with his bomb under Parliament, and how it would compare to what they would dohe was Muslim. You look over your shoulder at the door, and youaposre glad no-oneaposs come along yet. Maybe you wish him luck, and tell him that as Fawkes said on the rack a desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy. First photos of how temporary House of Commons will look in £BILLION refurb   Maybe you will try to talk him out of it, or go to find a policeman in the hope heaposll get help and the people who put themselves above will finally listen to those left below. Perhaps youaposre prepared to be optimistic about his chances of getting the help he was promised, and that he needs. Me  I think Iaposd quietly turn around, close the door, stick my elbow in the fire alarm and then let him get on with it.

story: NewsNo looks set to block Russian interference report until after general electionIf the report by the Intelligence and Security Committee isnt published by Tuesday night, there wont be another chance until mid-DecemberShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV NewsRussian President Vladimir Putin "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Downing Street looks set to block a report on alleged Russian interference in UK elections until after the December general election . Dominic Grieve, chairman of the Intelligence and Security Committee of Parliament, sent the report to Boris Johnson on October  and urged the PM not to sit on it.If it is not published before Parliament is dissolved tomorrow night, there wonapost be another chance before the Commons s in December. But today, government insiders stressed such reports usually took about six weeks to be cleared for publication. It is understood the report is not yet cleared by the Cabinet Office. A Downing Street spokesman today refused to say when the report will be published, saying: There are processes reports such as this have to go through before publication, and the committee is well informed of these.  Meanwhile a No source hit out at leaks from the committee, after it was reported that the report will present no evidence of Russian state interference in the EU referendum. The source said: The ISC doesnapost leak, it shouldnapost leak and this one has, in a very selective way. That has caused genuine concern. Former attorney general Dominic Grieve raised concerns about the report last week. He told MPs: The committee has been investigating the threat posed to this country by Russia. Weaposve produced a report which, in accordance with the Justice and Security Act, we sent to the Prime Minister on October  for him to confirm that there were no classied matters remaining - and there ought not to be because itaposs already been carefully looked at by the Cabinet Office.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe race to succeed John Bercow as Commons Speaker takes place this afternoon as MPs jostle for one of the most powerful jobs in British politics. MPs are electing a new Speaker for the first time in  years - less than  hours before Parliament dissolves for a general election. On the same day Mr Bercow - a former Tory - will resign as MP for Buckingham - leading to a race in his seat. But that contest will likely now be lumped in with the pending election. Current deputy Sir Lindsay Hoyle is the favourite while Labour grandee Harriet Harman is bidding to become only the second woman to hold the post. Todayaposs winner wonapost automatically be the Speaker in the next Parliament. But theyaposll be put forward as a single candidate to be aposconfirmedapos by MPs - so theyaposre pretty likely to keep the role. OnlyMPs vote down the new Speaker in December will there be another full ballot.  It comes after Mr Bercow - regularly accused of anti-Brexit bias but hailed as a hero of Parliament by his fans - finally announced he will bow out after a decade. The Speaker wept as he announced he would quit on October  in a declaration watched by his we Sally. The timing of his resignation was no coincidence. It meant the current Parliament - not a new one - could choose his replacement. That is important because it means a group of MPs who are against a hard, no-deal Brexit will be choosing the next person to oversee the legislature. Many of them are bowing out when Parliament dissolves on Wednesday So how will the Speaker election work and who is running  Heres everything you need to know.  MPs are voting for a new Speaker on Monday  November - the same sitting day that John Bercow quits as an MP. Candidates must submit their nomination papers, signed by at least  MPs from at three parties, to Commons authorities between .am and .am on the day of the election. Names of all the approved candidates are then published at am before a snap hustings in the Commons chamber at .pm - consisting of a speech from each hopeful. In the Speakeraposs chair for the debate will be Ken Clarke, the veteran Tory, because he is aposFather of the Houseapos - the longest continuously-serving MP in the Commons. MPs will then be given half an hour to vote for their favourite candidate on a ballot paper. If no single candidate wins more than % of the vote, the lowest-ranked candidateis eliminated and there is another round of voting. This continues until one candidate has won more than % of the total votes from MPs. A motion is then put to the Commons proposing the winner as Speaker. It can go to a vote again but by this point, they are likely to win. Traditionally the Speaker is dragged to the grand seat, supposedly against their will. Confirmed candidates Lindsay Hoyle Labour, Chorley, age . Odds:    The Lancashire-born businessman went to private Lordaposs College in Bolton and ran his own screen-printing firm before becoming an MP in . He has been a Deputy Speaker for nine years where his no-nonsense manner led to clashes with MPs - including telling off the SNP for singing EU anthem Ode to Joy in . In the same week he had a fierce clash with ex-SNP leader Alex Salmond, with the pair shouting at each other across the chamber over time slots given to Brexit scrutiny. Despite this Mr Hoyle is generally regarded as a popular figure who hasnapost made enemies in the same way as Bercow. There was an outpouring of tributes in  when his -year-old daughter Natalie was found dead. An inquest recorded an open verdict. Mr Hoyle was one of just three Labour MPs who did not declare their voting intention in the  EU referendum. His Lancashire district backed Brexit by % to %. Harriet Harman Labour, Camberwell  Peckham, age . Odds:     As Westminsteraposs longest-serving female MP, the QC is known as the Mother of the House with  yearsapos unbroken service. She spent more than two decades on the Labour front bench including as Deputy Labour Leader, Tony Blairaposs first Minister for Women and Leader of the House of Commons.  Born in London and educated at private St Paulaposs Girlsapos School, Ms Harman worked for the National Council for Civil Libertiesbefore becoming an MP in . Following a torrent of stories in the Daily Mail, she later said she regretted the NCCLaposs decision to grant affiliate status to a pro-paedophile group before she joined the staff. When she was elected barely  women had served in the Commons in its history. Her decades of activism for womenaposs rights led to mockery from right-wing pundits, including when she toured a pink bus round the country in . Her four-month stint as acting Labour leader, before Jeremy Corbyn took power, was marked by her decision not to oppose cruel Tory tax credit cuts that were later scrapped. Other controversies included being banned from driving in  after she was caught speeding at mph on the M. While in government she also tried to block the release of detailed Parliamentary expenses data. Due to her long experience and cross-party reputation, her name has been put forward as a possible caretaker Prime Ministerthe government loses a no confidence vote. Ms Harman was a prominent Remain-backer in  and though she has promised to be scrupulously neutral on Brexit, she has also warned she will be a champion for Parliamentelected. Her warning that she will take a robust stance could spark fears she will be a continuity John Bercow. Dame Eleanor Laing Conservative, Epping Forest, age . Odds:     The privately-educated solicitor from Paisley has spent six of her  years in Parliament as a Deputy Speaker, meaning she did not declare how she voted in the  EU referendum. She was a Special Advisor during the Thatcher and Major governments, and after her  election was an early Tory backer of equalising the age of consent at  for gay men. But she attracted controversy in  when she allegedly criticised a pregnant MP for leaving a debate to eat. She also voluntarily repaid £, during the  MPsapos expenses scandal over claims relating to a second home. Announcing her candidacy, she said the next Speaker should definitely be a woman as people need a breath of fresh air in Parliament. Meg Hillier Labour, Hackney South  Shoreditch, age . Odds: Not available  The privately-schooled former journalist and councillor served on the London Assembly before her election in . As Gordon Brownaposs Identity Minister she was tasked with promoting the failed ID card scheme - but was left red-faced in  when forgetting her own ID card at a photoshoot. She later served as Shadow Energy Secretary under Ed Miliband before rising to prominence as the hard-bitten chair of the powerful Public Accounts Committee. Pro-EU Ms Hillier voted Remain in the  referendum, voted against triggering Article  in , and earlier this year said Parliament should seriously consider delaying or revoking Article  to cancel Brexit. Chris Bryant Labour, Rhondda, age . Odds:     The privately-schooled former Church of England vicar dabbled with Conservatism as a student, before leaving the priesthood in  when he realised other members of the church believed the Bible doesnapost really like gays. He moved to London and rose through the ranks of the capitalaposs Labour groups through the s before his election to Parliament in . He shot to prominence soon afterwards for his role exposing wrongdoing in the press, including extracting a confession by then-Sun editor Rebekah Wade in  that the paper had paid the police for information in the past. He has become an outspoken voice on skin cancer after discovering he had melanoma on a trip to the barber. The MP voted Remain in the  referendum and said the whole country should have a chance to hold a second referendum on Brexit. His opening offer to MPs marked him out from John Bercow, emphasising that he would stick to rules and fairness. Dame Rosie Winterton Labour, Doncaster Central, age . Odds:  Not available  The privately-educated MP began her career as John Prescottaposs assistant in the s before her election to Parliament in . She spent almost a decade on Labouraposs front bench under Tony Blair and Gordon Brown before becoming the partyaposs Chief Whip in . Her six years in the top job presided over a tumultuous time in the party when more than  Labour MPs voted no confidence in Jeremy Corbyn but he refused to quit. Before becoming a deputy speaker in , which bound her to rules of impartiality, Dame Rosie voted Remain in the EU referendum but said it was important to respect the nationaposs vote to leave - including in her Doncaster seat. Sir Edward Leigh Conservative, Gainsborough, age . Odds:    The privately-educated veteran MP since  has only an outside chance due to his tub-thumping backing for Brexit. He has highly conservative views on social issues including backing the anti-gay Section  and voting against civil partnerships. Briefly a junior minister under John Major, the MP has spent all but three of his  years in Parliament as a backbencher including on the trade, procedure and parliamentary restoration committees.

Umer Riza,,  says he will take his legal battle to the highest court in the UK after receiving a apospassapos grade in his degree three years ago. He has tried to seek £, in damages from the University of South Wales over his  grade. Mr Riaz, who received the equivalent of a third class degree, said: Iaposm going to fight this evenI have to take it higher, even to the UN, reports Wales Online.  The student, who came to Cardf to study from Islamabad, Pakistan, claims he was not given the opportunity to continue his studies to complete an honours degree instead of a pass grade.  But his claim was struck out of county court in Cardf on Thursday after being described by the university as having no prospect of success. Mr Riaz added: Iaposm very, very keen that I take it as high as I can. A spokeswoman for the University of South Wales said all processes were followed fairly and accurately. Mr Riaz started his BSc hons chemistry degree in  but re-sat his first year after failing to get the credits needed. In , after suffering from poor health, the student said he suffered a fall on site, causing his second year modules to be deferred until the next year. As a result, Mr Riaz did not cover enough credits for an honours degree, and reached the maximum registration period for his course.  In a claim brought against the university, the international student described its decision not to allow him to take outstanding modules as unreasonable. But the university said Mr Riazaposs claim failed to particularise any cause of action and that arguments of unreasonableness did not fall under the courtaposs jurisdiction. Mr Riaz, who represented himself, said: I was quite good at my studies and I passed my English courses back home. I was the youngest and my family wanted to give me the opportunity for higher study. My parents are illiterate, they didnapost go to school. He added: A pass doesnapost mean anything to me. Having a pass degree is not going to help me to get anything.
